channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Explorer dies in Antarctic crossing
item.description: Explorer Henry Worsley dies during a solo attempt to cross Antarctica and complete the unfinished journey of his hero Sir Ernest Shackleton.

item.title: 999 crews 'should share control rooms'
item.description: Police, fire and ambulance services in England should share control rooms to improve their response to 999 calls, a Home Office minister says.

item.title: Zika virus 'to spread across Americas'
item.description: The Zika virus is likely to spread across nearly all of the Americas, the World Health Organization has warned.

item.title: 'Putin is corrupt' says US Treasury
item.description: The US Treasury tells the BBC that it considers Russia's President Putin to be corrupt - and many of his aides are already under Western sanctions.

item.title: US storm to bring heavy rain to UK
item.description: Heavy rain and gale-force winds are set to batter western parts of the UK with the arrival of the storm that hit the US with blizzards.

item.title: One in five home cover claims rejected
item.description: More than one in five home insurance claims are unsuccessful owing, in part, to the complexity of policies.

item.title: Oil prices in reverse amid Opec call
item.description: Oil prices tumble again on Monday, as Opec calls for co-operation from oil producing nations outside the organisation.

item.title: Pressure grows over Syrian refugee call
item.description: Ex-cabinet minister Sir Eric Pickles adds his voice to those calling on the UK to take in unaccompanied refugee children who have made it into Europe.

item.title: UN backs Colombia peace deal mission
item.description: The UN Security Council approves an unarmed mission in Colombia to oversee a ceasefire, if Farc rebels and the government sign a peace deal.

item.title: Cameron focused on 'size of EU prize'
item.description: David Cameron says agreement on renegotiating Britain's EU membership is possible next month but it has to be the "right deal" for the UK.

item.title: Tributes paid to Cecil Parkinson
item.description: Lord Parkinson, who as Conservative chairman played a key role in Margaret Thatcher's 1983 election victory, has died aged 84.

item.title: Tube strike called off by union
item.description: A 24-hour Underground strike planned to start on Tuesday evening is called off as the Rail, Maritime and Transport (RMT) suspends its action.

item.title: VIDEO: Explorer's poignant audio message
item.description: Part of the final audio message from Henry Worsley, who has died after suffering exhaustion and dehydration during an attempt to cross Antarctica unaided.

item.title: VIDEO: Drone footage of US snow - in 60 seconds
item.description: Drone footage captures some of the scenes following the snow storm that gripped many parts of the United States.

item.title: VIDEO: Are 'evil spirits' causing fires in Egypt?
item.description: A village in northern Egypt has been gripped by panic after dozens of houses were burnt in a series of mysterious fires.

item.title: VIDEO: Captain Hartley to 'lead by example'
item.description: Controversial hooker Dylan Hartley says he has "learned from his lessons" after being named England captain for the Six Nations.

item.title: VIDEO: Banksy art criticises treatment of refugees
item.description: The latest artwork by Banksy artwork criticises the apparent use of teargas on refugees in the Calais "Jungle" camp.

item.title: VIDEO: Why are whales washing up on UK beaches?
item.description: Five sperm whales have washed up on beaches in Lincolnshire and Norfolk.

item.title: VIDEO: Panda suit man pledges 'snow battle'
item.description: Maryland-based Jeffrey Perez dressed up as a panda imitating the snow-based actions of the Smithsonian Zoo's Tian Tian.

item.title: VIDEO: Aerial video shows 'frozen' East Asia
item.description: Aerial footage has shown the extent of a cold snap sweeping across East Asia - including frozen lakes and mudflats.

item.title: iPhone and China: Apple's Achilles' heel
item.description: After a huge 2015, Apple's 2016 may not be quite so plain sailing, writes Dave Lee.

item.title: Can a law abolish snobbery?
item.description: Why does the government feel it has to legislate to force schools to invite in providers of vocational training?

item.title: A tax deal in the hand is worth two in the bush
item.description: We'd all like to cut a deal with the taxman, but why is it only the big guys who are given the chance?

item.title: Egypt's revolutionaries - where are they now?
item.description: Five years on, the activists who spearheaded the protests in Egypt that led to the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak have met different fates.

item.title: US family saves piglet from blizzard
item.description: A family nurses a piglet back to health with banana and cereal after pulling him out of mounting piles of snow on the side of a road.

item.title: Police enter homes and tweet photos
item.description: Police in Coventry are criticised on social media for entering people's unlocked homes and tweeting photos, in an anti-burglary drive.

item.title: I have learned my lessons - Hartley
item.description: Dylan Hartley says he has "learned from his lessons" after being appointed England captain for the Six Nations.

item.title: Ramires nears Chelsea exit for China
item.description: Midfielder Ramires is set to leave Chelsea to become the biggest signing in the history of China's Jiangsu Suning.

item.title: Greenock Morton 0-2 Rangers
item.description: Rangers increase their lead at the Scottish Championship summit to five points with victory over Morton at Cappielow.

item.title: England face battle to avoid defeat
item.description: England close day four of the final Test against South Africa on 52-3, having been set an improbable 382 to win.

item.title: ECB's Draghi vows to defy critics
item.description: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi fights critics, insisting the bank's policies will help to raise inflation.

item.title: Toy Fair: Retro toys tipped for growth
item.description: Scalextric and Thunderbirds are among the retro toys that the toy industry hopes will drive growth this year.

item.title: Ministers lose Lords child poverty vote
item.description: The Bishop of Durham leads calls for ministers to report annually on income levels in the poorest households as ministers lose a Lords vote on child poverty.

item.title: EU vote: Sides clash over single market
item.description: "In" campaigners say full access to Europe's single market is vital for UK businesses, but critics dispute the benefits of EU membership to UK export growth.

item.title: Osborne pledges cash to beat malaria
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne and philanthropist Bill Gates announce £3bn in funding over the next five years to tackle malaria.

item.title: Toxic paint levels at playgrounds
item.description: Paint on playground equipment has been found to contain high amounts of the toxin lead - sometimes 40 times the recommended levels, research suggests.

item.title: Faith school places objections limited
item.description: Secularist campaign groups are to be stopped from making "vexatious complaints" against the admissions systems of individual faith schools.

item.title: Schools 'must offer apprenticeships'
item.description: Schools in England will have to give as much time to vocational routes as academic subjects in an effort to help students who want to land apprenticeships.

item.title: Council staff punished for net abuse
item.description: There was a rise in the number of council workers suspended last year after being accused of breaking social media rules.

item.title: Vtech restores some online services
item.description: Children's toy firm Vtech reopens "key functions" of its Learning Lodge gateway for the first time since it was hacked in November 2015.

item.title: Lanky bird's killer kick quantified
item.description: The secretary bird kicks snakes to death with a strike that packs five times the bird's own weight in a fraction of a second, scientists say.

item.title: VIDEO: Penguin diary: Charting a year in the life
item.description: Victoria Gill joins a team of scientists as they set up remote cameras to observe penguin colonies in the Antarctic.

item.title: Ofcom: Jekyll and Hyde 'on too early'
item.description: The first episode of ITV fantasy drama Jekyll and Hyde was broadcast too early to be suitable for young children, Ofcom rules.

item.title: X-Files TV return divides critics
item.description: Critics are divided in their opinion of the return of the cult sci-fi series The X-Files, which premiered in the US on Sunday.

item.title: How does the lottery investigate damaged tickets?
item.description: A woman says her winning lottery ticket got damaged in the wash - but what does the lottery do about such claims?

item.title: Swimming with elephants and sharks
item.description: Ali Bin Thalith grew up in Dubai where both his father and grandfather were pearl divers - he's now a photographer, specialising in underwater images.

item.title: Your pictures: Black and white
item.description: Readers' photographs on the theme of black and white

item.title: In pictures: The world's largest salt flat
item.description: The world's biggest salt flat

item.title: 'Traditionally submissive Muslim women' say who us?
item.description: Muslim women tell PM they are not 'traditionally submissive'

item.title: Perfect conditions for 'snow-swimming'
item.description: US storm prompts trend for 'snow-swimming'

item.title: Why do sperm whales wash up on beaches?
item.description: Why do sperm whales die in the North Sea?

item.title: Is Land Rover's off-road heyday over?
item.description: Is Land Rover's off-road heyday over?

item.title: The Duchess and the Afghan coat lady
item.description: What happens to people who cannot be identified after death?

item.title: The children who need to play
item.description: The children far from home but determined to play
